text_original: It was 28 years since my daughter Marie died. The doctors said she had a blood clot but I didn't believe them. I continuously shouted "You KILLED my daughter!" It was a long night and we had to notify multiple family members, including my other daughter Rita. She was making a hot pot of tea in the kitchen and looking outside towards Wolf Street. She collapsed when she heard the news and my husband had a heart attack. My little sister even brought a big orange to give to Marie but never got the chance. My son Micheal also had a heart attack from the shocking news. Hard to believe but yes they both did. There was another mother losing her daughter in the room before mine. I prayed and prayed for God to keep her alive for her mother. Even after so many years, is it still very painful for Rita to remember the news. She suffers from crippling depression for weeks and sometimes months at a time. It was a cold winter month when it happened. Probably closer to April from my memory. I put on a big coat and boots before leaving to the hospital.
text_again: It was a cold winter day in April. My daughter was rushed to the hospital after collapsing on the ground. I didn't know what was wrong or what I should do. Her room was shared with another girl and her mother. I prayed that her daughter was going to be okay. I cant imagine that kind of pain as a mother. The doctors said she wasn't doing well and had multiple blood clots. They moved me to another room and told me my daughter isn't going to make it. I was screaming that they killed her after it happened. They tried to calm me down. I remember I had so many heavy layers on and I felt like I weighed a million pounds. Everything was a blur after that. I had to tell my husband next. He collapsed of a heart attack when I told him the news. My other daughter Rita was just making a coffee when she heard. Everyone was screaming with pain. My son had one of the worst reactions to the news. We sat all of her aunts and uncles down together in the tea room as well.

Mrs Costa's daughter Marie was in the hospital. She went to visit Marie and was curious about why the chair was out, the nurse told her that it was to put her in, which confused Mrs Costa.
The father was at home, having washed and shaved, and sitting on the porch, waiting.
Mrs Costa had prepared coffee, as Marie always liked the first coffee in the morning, and had asked Marie's sister to get some cake from the bakery.
Mrs Costa went to the hospital to see Marie, with a coat underneath her arm. When she got to the hospital, the nurse's assistant was present. One of Mrs Costa's neighbours was seriously unwell, and she was very worried about her, and her ten children.
One of the nurses approached her and asked if Marie ever had any fainting spells, which caused anxiety. When visiting Marie, it was noticed that she was unwell and had large beads of sweat. Moments after, Marie passed away and Mrs Costa broke down in rage. It was from a blood-clot that Mrs Costa believed was caused by the chair depicted earlier.
Everyone back home and at the store was wondering where Mrs Costa was, including a sister-in-law who had brought a notably large orange.
Marie's sister went to the hospital and saw Mrs Costa in the corridor, and it was revealed that Marie had died. She collapsed to the floor upon hearing the news, and her leg went solid like a pole, which often results of weeks of pain. The doctors offered Mrs Costa something to help, as they were familiar with her as she had already been in hospital herself for several operations.
When they went home, it was clear the news was bad as Mrs Costa did not look well and had been picking at her hair.
The news was revealed to people in the neighbourhood, including to a young boy over the telephone, who then revealed the news to his two aunts while in tears.

So, there was a woman whose daughter, Marie, died almost twenty eight years ago this month. Marie had surgery at Methodist Hospital for appendicitis. The operation took place late on a Saturday afternoon.
The next day, Marie’s older sister, Victoria, went to visit her. At that time, they used a lot of ether during surgery, and Marie was still under its effects. There was a chair in the room because the hospital staff was beginning to get patients out of bed, but Marie was still too sick to be moved. Victoria questioned the nurse about the chair, and the nurse explained that it was the doctor’s orders to get her out of bed. Victoria was worried since Marie was still unconscious, but they insisted.
Later that afternoon, the woman was at home when she got a call from a neighbor at the store. The hospital had called, saying Marie was being discharged and that she needed to go pick her up. She told her daughter Rita to finish cooking and prepare coffee, as Marie always liked to have a cup of coffee first thing in the morning.
She prepared herself, taking her coat and Marie’s dress with her, and went to the hospital. When she arrived, the nurse asked her to sit down for a moment. While waiting, the woman prayed for another patient in the hospital, a mother with ten children who was in very bad shape.
Suddenly, the woman started to feel chills and cold sweats. The nurses noticed and asked if Marie had ever fainted before. Realizing something was seriously wrong, they rushed her into Marie’s room.
Marie was lying there in her slippers and housecoat, sweating heavily. The woman was devastated and accused the staff of killing her daughter. The doctor, a lady named Dr. Montique who assisted Dr. Schwartz during the operation, came in but admitted they didn’t know what had happened.
The woman became hysterical, pulling at her hair and banging her head against the wall. Marie was only eighteen years old, beautiful, and was supposed to be going home that day. But just as the woman turned her back, Marie passed away.
At home, the woman’s husband was waiting anxiously. The hospital kept calling the store asking when Marie’s mother would arrive, not knowing the tragedy that had happened.
The woman was so distraught that a doctor wanted to give her a sedative, but she refused, telling them they had already taken her daughter’s life, and she wasn’t about to let them take hers too.
Her daughter Rita came to the hospital, and when she saw her mother’s state, she collapsed on the floor from shock. Ever since that day, Rita has suffered from terrible pain in her leg like a hard pole running through it that lasts for weeks and makes walking difficult.

The cause of Marie’s death was later determined to be a blood clot. A girl who had been with Marie said that Marie had complained of pain in her leg and blindness before collapsing.

The woman was furious and refused to let anyone touch Marie’s body afterward.

When she finally went home, she was screaming loudly, drawing the attention of neighbors. She told her husband what had happened—they had lost Marie.

The entire family and neighborhood were shocked. Annie, a woman from the local store, still remembers Marie standing quietly on the step, a good and pleasant girl.

The woman’s younger sister had brought an orange for Marie and asked to be informed when Marie was picked up so they could come over. The woman called her brother-in-law, an undertaker, but sent her young son James to tell other family members instead. James was crying when he delivered the sad news.

It was a tragedy that affected everyone close to the family.

text_original: Marie Costas got sick and had an operation at a Methodist hospital on the afternoon of April 20, 28 years ago. It was a chilly day. Her mother narrates the story in the first person as she recalls what happened. Her daughter Victoria visited Marie in the hospital and wondered why there was a chair beside the bed. The nurse explained that Marie was expected to try to get out of bed and sit in the chair. Victoria felt it was too soon, but the nurse insisted they were the doctor's orders. Marie tried to get up but fell back on the bed. Marie's mother reflects, in hindsight, that this was evidence of the blood clot that would later take her life. Marie's mother said she was expecting to go and pick Marie up after her surgery, as soon as she was sufficiently recovered to return home. She didn't have a telephone in those days, but the lady at the local store had one, so on April 30, ten days after the operation, the hospital called the lady at the store and asked her to pass on the message to Marie's mother that she was ready to be discharged. Marie's mother told her daughter Rita to make a big pot of coffee in preparation for her sister's return, because Marie always loved coffee. The first cup of coffee every morning was set aside for Marie. Marie's clothes were ready and waiting on the kitchen table, so Marie's mother gathered them up and went to the hospital, with Marie's coat and dress over her arm. Meanwhile, Marie's father Mike went upstairs and shaved, then waited on the front steps for his daughter to come home. When Marie's mother got to the hospital, she was waiting patiently for Marie and praying for another woman she knew of in the same hospital who had surgery on her gallbladder. That woman had ten children, so Marie's mother prayed "please don't let those children lose their mother." Then she heard a young nurse's aide telling another nurse that a patient had broken out in a cold sweat. The nurse hung up the phone, and Marie's mother said "please tell me you're not talking about my daughter." They all rushed to Marie's room, where they saw her, still dressed in her housecoat. She had big drops of sweat visible on her skin and looked very ill. The male surgeon who had operated on Marie was not present, but a female doctor came to assess the situation. Marie's mother asked her what was wrong with Marie, but the doctor said she didn't know. Just as Marie's mother turned her back on her daughter, Marie died. Marie's mother was utterly distraught and described herself as hysterial. She was screaming and tearing out her hair. She wanted to know what had gone wrong, but nobody could tell her. The doctor and nurses wanted to sedate Marie's mother because she was so distraught and beating her head against the wall in an outburst of grief. Marie's mother adamantly refused to be sedated. Meanwhile, the people in the hospital's office didn't know Marie had died and were repeatedly trying to contact her family to come and collect her. They called the woman at the store, who contacted Marie. Marie's mother had a son-in-law who drove Rita to the hospital, where she found her mother. "Marie has died," she told her daughter, and Rita immediately collapsed to the ground. Her leg was rigid like a pole due to the trauma of the fall, and Marie's mother explains that to this day she has a phlebitis-like pain in that leg for 8 or 9 weeks at a time. The doctor implied that she wanted to examine Marie's body, or possibly do an autopsy, to find out what killed her. Marie's mother refused, saying they must find out what killed her, but they were not to touch her daughter's remains. Marie's mother returned home with Rita, where Marie's father Mike was waiting. He asked what happened, and Marie's mother explained that Rita died. Mike was so distraught that he had a heart attack, then and there, in the kitchen. Then their son Michael came home and they broke the news to him. He too had a heart attack. Marie's mother had two sisters who had wanted her to let them know as soon as Marie came home. One of them had an orange for Marie, and it was an extraordinarily large orange. Marie's mother told her son Jamie, who was then a little boy, to run to the home of of his aunts and break the news. His aunts had been cleaning the pavement, and it was clean and shiny as Jamie came running towards them. "Marie has died," he said. The lady who owned the store and has passed on phone message from the hospital would later tell Marie's mother that Marie was always a gentle and quiet presence in her store.
